conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two objects, A and B, moving along the same line with velocities plotted against time.
In a velocity-time graph, the slope represents acceleration.
Object A has a constant acceleration because its graph is a straight line.
Object B has a changing acceleration because its graph is curved.
At t=0, the velocity of B is positive, and the curve is concave up.
Analyzing tangent lines helps determine how acceleration changes over time.
At t=0, the tangent line is steep, indicating high positive acceleration.
Between t=0 and t1, the tangent line is less steep, suggesting decreased acceleration.
At t=t1, the tangent line is almost horizontal, meaning acceleration is close to zero.
Between t1 and t2, the tangent line becomes steeper, indicating increased positive acceleration.
From t=0 to t1, acceleration decreases from high positive to almost zero.
From t1 to t2, acceleration increases from almost zero to higher positive.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, so a=dv/dt.
Between t=0 and t1, velocity decreases but is positive, so dv/dt is positive but decreasing.
At t1, velocity reaches a minimum, and dv/dt is zero.
Between t1 and t2, velocity increases, so dv/dt is positive and increasing.
Overall trend: acceleration decreases to zero and then increases.
Velocity is positive throughout, with a minimum at t1.
No negative acceleration is present since velocity is always positive.
Final answer: acceleration trend is decreasing to zero and then increasing.
